channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: California's largest workers' comp insurer eases eligibility requirements for coronavirus claims
item.dc:creator: Kim Christensen, Anita Chabria
item.description: California's largest workers' compensation insurer has lifted a requirement that essential workers with COVID-19 prove they contracted the virus on the job.
item.content:encoded: California's largest workers' compensation insurer has lifted a requirement that essential workers with COVID-19 prove they contracted the virus on the job.

media:content.media:description: Members of the Los Angeles Fire Department conduct COVID-19 testing on Skid Row in Los Angeles on Tuesday.

item.title: Tickets for speeding in excess of 100 mph surge 87% amid coronavirus shutdown, CHP says
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California shutdown: CHP sees 87% increase in tickets for drivers going more than 100 mph amid coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: California shutdown: CHP sees 87% increase in tickets for drivers going more than 100 mph amid coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA, WEDNESDAY MARCH 25, 2020 - Traffic is light as rush hour looms at the intersection of the 110 and the 105 freeways. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Robert Gauthier/Robert Gauthier/Robert Gauthier/Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Following coronavirus closure, Mt. Baldy ski resort reopening in limited capacity
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The plan to reopen the San Bernardino County ski destination in a limited capacity marks the latest effort to allow limited recreation amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The plan to reopen the San Bernardino County ski destination in a limited capacity marks the latest effort to allow limited recreation amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: MT. BALDY, CALIF. -- SATURDAY, JANUARY 18, 2020: A skiers rides a lift among large pines at Mt. Baldy ski resort in Mt. Baldy, Calif., on Jan. 18, 2020. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Kristin Smart cold case: New warrant served at San Pedro home of former classmate
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Investigators have served a search warrant at the home of a former Cal Poly San Luis Obispo classmate of Kristin Smart, who disappeared 24 years ago.
item.content:encoded: Investigators have served a search warrant at the home of a former Cal Poly San Luis Obispo classmate of Kristin Smart, who disappeared 24 years ago.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CALIFORNIA—FEB. 5, 2020—Sheriff deputies search the home of a suspect Paul Flores in the case of missing student Kristin Smart who vanished from Cal Poly San Luis Obispo nearly 24 years ago. The suspect was released after a thorough check of his home and vehicles at 937 West Upland in San Pedro, California on Feb. 5, 2020. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: These eerie photos show LAX as a ghost town. Passenger air travel is down more than 90%
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Photos from LAX, where a handful of passengers still pass through the terminals, with air traffic nationwide down due to the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Photos from LAX, where a handful of passengers still pass through the terminals, with air traffic nationwide down due to the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- APRIL 21: A lone passenger wearing personal protective equipment wonders through an empty Tom Bradley International Terminal as the coronavirus outbreak has brought passenger traffic to a near halt with travel down 95% at LosAngeles International Airport, the nation's second busiest, on Tuesday, April 21, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Street racers are taking over roads emptied by coronavirus, with fatal results
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Richard Winton
item.description: California shutdown: Street racers are taking over road emptied by coronavirus, with fatal results
item.content:encoded: California shutdown: Street racers are taking over road emptied by coronavirus, with fatal results

media:content.media:description: Illegal Street racing activities on Ana Street in Compton on Apr. 13, 2015. One of the several illegal street racing locations racers raced.
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Tulare County demands action after coronavirus outbreak kills 15 at one nursing home
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak at Redwood Springs Healthcare Center in Visalia accounts for more than half the reported cases in Tulare County.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus outbreak at Redwood Springs Healthcare Center in Visalia accounts for more than half the reported cases in Tulare County.

media:content.media:description: The Redwood Springs Healthcare Center, a skilled nursing facility in Visalia, announced two healthcare staff members and six patients had tested positive for COVID-19.

item.title: Coronavirus slashing money immigrants send home by 20%, creating second economic crisis
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Remittances will fall by 20%, from $554 billion in 2019 to an expected $445 billion this year, the World Bank warned.
item.content:encoded: Remittances will fall by 20%, from $554 billion in 2019 to an expected $445 billion this year, the World Bank warned.

media:content.media:description: Remittances to most Latin American countries have picked up again after slumping during the Great Recession. But money sent by Mexican immigrants to their homeland this year, an estimated $22 billion, remains 29% off its 2006 peak, the Pew Research Center reports Friday in a study of flows and trends over 13 years.

item.title: 'Second wave' of coronavirus could be far worse for California than the first, officials warn
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Matt Hamilton, Luke Money, Paige St. John, Deborah Netburn
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom and others have said the worst of coronavirus may be yet to come and lifting stay-at-home orders now could be disastrous.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom and others have said the worst of coronavirus may be yet to come and lifting stay-at-home orders now could be disastrous.

media:content.media:description: ##PATIENT PROVIDED VERBAL CONSENT TO HOSPITAL REPRESENTATIVES## CHULA VISTA, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 2020: RN Arnold Garcia collects a sample for a coronavirus test from Michael Weiss after he was admitted with possible COVID-19 symptoms at Sharp Chula Vista Medical Center in Chula Vista, Calif., on April 10, 2020. On the left, RN Shauna Stanfill supervises. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Are homeless shelters 'a nasty experiment' during coronavirus? L.A. says no and opens more
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes, Doug Smith
item.description: Coronavirus outbreaks have hit many homeless shelters across the country. But L.A. is moving forward with a plan to open shelters in recreation centers.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus outbreaks have hit many homeless shelters across the country. But L.A. is moving forward with a plan to open shelters in recreation centers.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, MARCH 20, 2020: LA City parks and recreation staff along with volunteers from the Salvation Army set up cots for homeless at Westwood Recreation Center in Westwood, Calif., on March 20, 2020. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: UC experts drop new ammunition against the SAT and ACT as an admissions requirement
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Three University of California admissions experts slammed a faculty recommendation to keep the SAT and ACT for at least five years, giving ammunition to critics of the controversial exams who want to drop their requirement for admissions.
item.content:encoded: Three University of California admissions experts slammed a faculty recommendation to keep the SAT and ACT for at least five years, giving ammunition to critics of the controversial exams who want to drop their requirement for admissions.

media:content.media:description: A recent decision by the College Board to return the SAT's main test to two parts -- math and reading -- has sparked a debate among colleges about whether to require applicants to take an optional essay portion.

item.title: Orange County debates closing beaches as hot weather raises fears of out-of-town crowds
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: With the upcoming heat wave, Orange County worries out-of-towners will descend on beaches in droves, raising the risk of coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: With the upcoming heat wave, Orange County worries out-of-towners will descend on beaches in droves, raising the risk of coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF. -- THURSDAY, APRIL 2, 2020: Kylie Wortham, 18, of Huntington Beach, who was laid off when her entire company was closed due to Coronavirus social distancing rules, relaxes with a book in a hammock overlooking the beach in Huntington Beach Thursday, April 2, 2020. The pier, beach parking lots and most shops are closed due to state-mandated Coronavirus social distancing rules. The area is normally teeming with spring break visitors. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Zoos struggle to find funds to feed animals, who seem to miss the crush of humanity
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: As people shelter in place amid the pandemic, zoos have lost ticket revenues needed for a major expense — feeding animals.
item.content:encoded: As people shelter in place amid the pandemic, zoos have lost ticket revenues needed for a major expense — feeding animals.

media:content.media:description: OAKLAND, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 20, 2020-Two mountain lions hang together in a hammock on April 20, 2020 at the Oakland Zoo. The arrived at the zoo as rescues. The Oakland Zoo is closed due to the coronavirus, leaving the zoo without ticket sales. The costs of operating the zoo is 2 million dollars per month. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here are the latest numbers of coronavirus cases in L.A. County communities
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Los Angeles County officials confirmed 1,400 more coronavirus cases, 880 of which came from a backlog. The death toll rises to 663.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County officials confirmed 1,400 more coronavirus cases, 880 of which came from a backlog. The death toll rises to 663.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, TUESDAY, APRIL 21 - Downtown shines in the setting sun looking East from MacArthur Park during the Coronavirus pandemic. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In rural California, children face isolation, hunger amid coronavirus school closures
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: Schools in rural parts of the state are struggling not only to teach but to reach students. Many lack internet access and rely on schools for food.
item.content:encoded: Schools in rural parts of the state are struggling not only to teach but to reach students. Many lack internet access and rely on schools for food.

media:content.media:description: Principal receives a thank you card.

item.title: Getting free internet is hard for poor students despite provider promises, survey finds
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli, Paloma Esquivel
item.description: Low-income L.A. families are struggling to get students connected to the internet even with promises of help from phone and cable providers. A survey found 16% still unconnected.
item.content:encoded: Low-income L.A. families are struggling to get students connected to the internet even with promises of help from phone and cable providers. A survey found 16% still unconnected.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 01, 2020 8-year-old 2nd grade student Paulina De Loza holds her computer issued at the Ellen Ochoa Learning Center in Cudahy while her Mother Yadire De Loza holds another computer for her 2 brothers also in LAUSD schools as some students in LAUSD are issued computers Wednesday morning April 1, 2020. The campuses are closed because of the coronavirus Covid 19, but 63 schools are being used to hand out computers. In addition, students are picking up computers and internet hotspots from schools as well as homework packets. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A.'s most crowded neighborhoods fear outbreaks: 'If one of us gets it, we are all going to get it'
item.dc:creator: Ben Poston, Tony Barboza, Ryan Menezes
item.description: Coronavirus: L.A.'s most crowded neighborhoods fear outbreaks: 'If one of us gets it, we are all going to get it'
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: L.A.'s most crowded neighborhoods fear outbreaks: 'If one of us gets it, we are all going to get it'

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - APR. 18, 2020. Alvarado Street in the Westlake District of Los Angeles, which has the second highest population density in the city, with about 38,214 people per square mile. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: The coronavirus pandemic has made one thing perfectly clear: It's time to split the country
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: After five weeks stuck at home watching cable news, I say it's time for California to secede.
item.content:encoded: After five weeks stuck at home watching cable news, I say it's time for California to secede.

media:content.media:description: Protesters from ReOpenNC fill Lane Street as they march calling on North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper to ease COVID-19 restrictions due to economic concerns on Tuesday, April 21, 2020 in Raleigh, N.C. (Robert Willett/The News & Observer via AP)

item.title: How do we craft the narratives that will define a pandemic? Look to the numbers
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: Unprecedented is the word used to describe the coronavirus pandemic. How do we tell a story that's never been told before?
item.content:encoded: Unprecedented is the word used to describe the coronavirus pandemic. How do we tell a story that's never been told before?

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK, USA - APRIL 1: A sad and tired healthcare worker is seen by the Brooklyn Hospital Center in New York, United States on April 1, 2020. New York is the U.S. state worst-hit by the pandemic. As New York state grapples with the novel coronavirus outbreak, 1,941 people have died and 83,712 have tested positive for the virus, Governor Andrew Cuomo said Wednesday. (Photo by Tayfun Coskun/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)
media:content.media:credit: Anadolu Agency/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images

item.title: 'Where are the strokes and the heart attacks?' Doctors worry as patients avoid ERs
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin
item.description: Amid fears that hospital emergency rooms are rife with coronavirus, fewer people with medical emergencies are seeking help.
item.content:encoded: Amid fears that hospital emergency rooms are rife with coronavirus, fewer people with medical emergencies are seeking help.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA-MARCH 18, 2020-An elderly man holds his hands up as if being questioned at the entrance to the emergency room at UCLA Medical Center. Testing for Covid-19 is going on at UCLA Medical Center. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Some sections of California are pushing to lift stay-at-home rules before others
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, John Myers, Luke Money, Hannah Fry
item.description: Officials this week are making a bid with Gov. Gavin Newsom to begin a slow and gradual reopening process, one they say is guided by science.
item.content:encoded: Officials this week are making a bid with Gov. Gavin Newsom to begin a slow and gradual reopening process, one they say is guided by science.

media:content.media:description: POINT MUGU, CA - APRIL 11: Visitors to Pt. Mugu ignore no parking as well as coronavirus and social distancing restrictions on Saturday, April 11, 2020 in Point Mugu, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: The Enneagram is having a moment. You can thank millennials
item.dc:creator: Marisa Gerber
item.description: The boom of the personality test is part of the same contemporary phenomenon that some observers connect to the resurgence of astrology.
item.content:encoded: The boom of the personality test is part of the same contemporary phenomenon that some observers connect to the resurgence of astrology.

media:content.media:description: Riverside, CA - September 20, 2019 - (L/R) Katie Pitman, Andrea Torres, Nicole Winkfield, Willy Villalpando and Kristin Bell connect in an interactive game that helps figure out the nine personality types in Enneagram. The booming popularity of Enneagram has lead to workshops and party gatherings. (Ana Venegas)
media:content.media:credit: Ana Venegas/For The Times/Ana Venegas/For The Times/Ana Venegas/For The Times

item.title: 3.7 earthquake hits South Los Angeles, causing light shaking across Southland
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II

item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.7 earthquake was reported early Wednesday near Inglewood, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak at Orange County nursing home kills two patients, sickens 72

item.content:encoded: Two patients from Huntington Valley Healthcare Center died of COVID-19 this week, and 48 other patients and 24 healthcare professionals have tested positive for the coronavirus, according to the company.

item.content:encoded: Moderate to strong winds and above-normal temperatures are on tap for Southern California

item.title: California bullet train officials reveal ethics probe and OK plan for L.A. Union Station
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.description: A California bullet train consultant facing allegations that it retaliated against employees for bringing forth negative information has hired a law firm to investigate the matter.
item.content:encoded: A California bullet train consultant facing allegations that it retaliated against employees for bringing forth negative information has hired a law firm to investigate the matter.

media:content.media:description: FRESNO, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 15, 2018: Construction of California's high-speed rail project in Fresno, Calif., on Aug. 15, 2018. Shown S. Cedar Ave. and SR-99. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Garcetti pushes law protecting displaced workers from being replaced by cheaper labor
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Colleen Shalby
item.description: The mayor said the idea was to prevent senior workers being replaced by newer, cheaper ones when the economy comes back.
item.content:encoded: The mayor said the idea was to prevent senior workers being replaced by newer, cheaper ones when the economy comes back.

item.title: L.A. County courts launch video hearings during coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: To cut down on courthouse traffic and promote social distancing, L.A. County begins video arraignments in 17 courthouses.
item.content:encoded: To cut down on courthouse traffic and promote social distancing, L.A. County begins video arraignments in 17 courthouses.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 21, 2020: Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Miguel Espinoza holds video arraignments in his courtroom at Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center on Tuesday, April 21, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Ventura County urges residents to keep social distancing despite coronavirus progress
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: County officials stressed that residents are still required to stay home as much as possible and practice social distancing inside businesses.
item.content:encoded: County officials stressed that residents are still required to stay home as much as possible and practice social distancing inside businesses.

media:content.media:description: PORT HUENEME, CA - APRIL 19: People enjoy a day at the beach after Ventura County modified its coronavirus stay-at-home order to permit some businesses to reopen and some activities and gatherings at Port Hueneme Beach Park on Sunday, April 19, 2020 in Port Hueneme, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.dc:creator: Lyndsay Winkley

item.title: California becomes first state to recommend coronavirus tests for some without symptoms
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner
item.description: California is now giving coronavirus testing priority to asymptomatic people in high-risk settings such as nursing homes and prisons.
item.content:encoded: California is now giving coronavirus testing priority to asymptomatic people in high-risk settings such as nursing homes and prisons.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-APRIL 8, 2020: A specimen is turned in at the new mobile testing site for people with symptoms of the coronavirus at Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on Wednesday, April 8, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: O.C. clears the way for golf courses to open amid coronavirus pandemic
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Orange County leaders agreed Tuesday to allow public and private golf courses to reopen amid a push from residents to begin easing restrictions and closures that have been in place because of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Orange County leaders agreed Tuesday to allow public and private golf courses to reopen amid a push from residents to begin easing restrictions and closures that have been in place because of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, MARCH 31, 2020: Golfers put on the 7th hole green of the Shorecliffs Golf Course, the last open public golf course in Orange County, amid Coronavirus social distancing regulations in San Clemente, Calif., on March 31, 2020. The pro shop, bar, and restraunt are closed. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Here is the latest list of Orange County communities with coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The number of confirmed coronavirus infections in Orange County grew to 1,691 Tuesday as health officials announced 29 new cases.
item.content:encoded: The number of confirmed coronavirus infections in Orange County grew to 1,691 Tuesday as health officials announced 29 new cases.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON, CA - APRIL 16: Medical personnel from St. Jude Medical Center stand clustered on the sidewalk as Fullerton and Brea Firefighters, EMS and Police join together in a show of support for healthcare workers outside of the St. Jude Medical Center on Thursday, April 16, 2020 in Fullerton, CA. The southland is entering the second month of "safer at home" orders in an effort to fight the coronavirs and COVID-19 pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California needs 'an army of volunteers' for its coronavirus response, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: The 'Californians for All' effort focuses on a new web-based application for those willing to volunteer in a variety of ways.
item.content:encoded: The 'Californians for All' effort focuses on a new web-based application for those willing to volunteer in a variety of ways.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom has launched a new state government-led effort to encourage Californians to volunteer in community efforts during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: California sets guidelines on which patients are prioritized if hospitals overwhelmed by coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: The guidelines aim to answer the troubling ethical question of who lives and who dies should California face a new surge in the coronavirus outbreak, resulting in a shortage of ventilators and medical supplies.
item.content:encoded: The guidelines aim to answer the troubling ethical question of who lives and who dies should California face a new surge in the coronavirus outbreak, resulting in a shortage of ventilators and medical supplies.

media:content.media:description: SAN DIEGO, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 2020: Patients arrive and are screened for COVID-19 symptoms at the medic staging area before entering the Sharp Memorial Hospital in San Diego, Calif., on April 10, 2020. As of Friday afternoon, there have been1,693 cases and 44 deathsamong San Diego County residents. Across California there have been19,472 cases and 541 deaths.(Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD will end controversial program that aimed to predict where crimes would occur
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Chief Moore says, due to financial constraints caused by the pandemic, the LAPD will end a program that predicts where property crimes could occur.
item.content:encoded: Chief Moore says, due to financial constraints caused by the pandemic, the LAPD will end a program that predicts where property crimes could occur.

media:content.media:description: TARZANA, CA-APRIL 24, 2019: LAPD Senior Lead Officers Denise Vasquez, left, and Oscar Bocanegra, patrol along Tampa Ave. in Tarzana, in a hot zone known as a predpole, which stands for predictive policing. The hot zones come from a computer analysis based off 10 years of crime data. The crime concern in this area based on the data is home burglaries. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gov. Newsom suggests he won't allow communities to lift stay-at-home orders for now

item.title: Leimert Park fire spares Vision Theatre during renovation
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Angel Jennings
item.description: No one was hurt in the fire, but a Facebook video showed debris littering the outside of the Vision Theatre, an Art Deco building that opened in 1931.
item.content:encoded: No one was hurt in the fire, but a Facebook video showed debris littering the outside of the Vision Theatre, an Art Deco building that opened in 1931.

media:content.media:description: The 1931 Art Deco Vision Theatre, which overlooks Leimert Park Plaza, is in the midst of an $11-million renovation by the city of Los Angeles.

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus cases top 15,000 as nearby locales mull lifting stay-at-home orders
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: L.A. County health officials confirmed 46 new COVID-19 deaths and 1,400 more coronavirus cases on Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County health officials confirmed 46 new COVID-19 deaths and 1,400 more coronavirus cases on Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: CHULA VISTA, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 2020: From left, RN Linda Isidienu, RN Michael Manriquez watch as Tiffany Matthews, a Respiratory Therapist, administers care for an intubated patient diagnosed with COVID-19, inside a negative pressure isolation room, at the Intensive Care Unit at Sharp Chula Vista Medical Center in Chula Vista, Calif., on April 10, 2020. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: "We do not want another Gabriel Fernandez' Coronavirus leads to 'alarming' drop in child abuse reports
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Since the coronavirus outbreak closed schools and largely hidden children at home, the reports of suspected abuse have dropped by as much as 50%.
item.content:encoded: Since the coronavirus outbreak closed schools and largely hidden children at home, the reports of suspected abuse have dropped by as much as 50%.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, MAY 29, 2019: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva holds a media briefing/open house event to discuss current events, at the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles, Calif., on May 29, 2019. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Cal State Fullerton preparing to go online this fall. Will others follow?
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe, Nina Agrawal
item.description: Cal State Fullerton says that amid coronavirus uncertainty it will prepare to start the fall semester with online instruction. Will other campuses follow suit?
item.content:encoded: Cal State Fullerton says that amid coronavirus uncertainty it will prepare to start the fall semester with online instruction. Will other campuses follow suit?

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON-CA-APRIL 21, 2020: Cal State University Fullerton student Linh Trinh, 21, right, and her boyfriend Tan Nguyen, 21, walk around a deserted CSUF campus on Tuesday, April 21, 2020. The school is planning to begin Fall semester with online classes, one of the first universities in the nation to make that move as campuses throughout the country grapple with how long to stay closed to most students amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Lewis MacAdams, famed crusader for the Los Angeles River, dies at 75
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: A local poet and lifelong environmental activist, MacAdams dedicated his life to restoring the Los Angeles River.
item.content:encoded: A local poet and lifelong environmental activist, MacAdams dedicated his life to restoring the Los Angeles River.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA., NOVEMBER 17, 2016: Lewis McAdams leans his head on a railing along a green stretch of the Los Angeles River in Elysian Valley, a few miles north of downtown Los Angeles November 17, 2016. McAdams, a local poet and lifelong environmental activist dedicated to restoring the Los Angeles River to a semblance of its natural state, is stepping down from his position as Director of Friends Of The Los Angeles River and is passing the torch to Marissa Christiansen November 17, 2016 (Mark Boster/ Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Coronavirus could become leading cause of death in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Melanie Mason
item.description: A study shows roughly 4% of L.A. County residents have contracted COVID-19, suggesting it might be less fatal locally than originally believed.
item.content:encoded: A study shows roughly 4% of L.A. County residents have contracted COVID-19, suggesting it might be less fatal locally than originally believed.

item.title: California acknowledges more than 850 coronavirus cases in assisted-living facilities
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton, Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: The data were released after an L.A. Times investigation. With older residents in close quarters, the homes are especially vulnerable to the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: The data were released after an L.A. Times investigation. With older residents in close quarters, the homes are especially vulnerable to the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, -MARCH 27, 2020: Silverado Beverly Place, a nursing home near the Fairfax District off of Beverly Boulevard. There were three cases of coronavirus after the nursing home took in a new resident. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coyotes, falcons, deer and other wildlife are reclaiming L.A. territory as humans stay at home

item.content:encoded: Some smaller California communities want to begin easing stay-at-home restrictions, saying they have made enough progress against the coronavirus.

(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Former UCLA soccer coach Jorge Salcedo to plead guilty in college admissions scandal
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Jorge Salcedo, an ex-UCLA soccer coach charged in the admission of two students for bribes, will plead guilty to conspiring to commit racketeering.
item.content:encoded: Jorge Salcedo, an ex-UCLA soccer coach charged in the admission of two students for bribes, will plead guilty to conspiring to commit racketeering.

media:content.media:description: Jorge Salcedo, former UCLA soccer coach, departs federal court in Boston on Monday, March 25, 2019, after faceing charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. (AP Photo/Steven Senne)

item.title: These are the latest coronavirus case numbers by community in L.A. County

item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: These are the latest numbers of cases by community in L.A. County

media:content.media:description: FOUNTAIN VALLEY, CA - APRIL 20, 2020 - Kayla Le, center, and Nguyen Nguyen, right, both wearing protective masks and gloves, take orders at Brodard Restaurant in Fountain Valley on April 20, 2020. Brodard's is one of Orange County's most famous Vietnamese Restaurants and is still doing take-out orders since the coronavirus shutdown many businesses. All employees wear safety masks and gloves and customers are required to wear a mask, but some do not comply. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 12 photos show skid row during pandemic — and the judge risking his life to help
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes, Photography by the staff of the Los Angeles Times
item.description: U.S. District Judge David O. Carter, long known as brash, verbose and stubbornly hands-on, has been on a mission to force changes in the living conditions for the homeless people of L.A.
item.content:encoded: U.S. District Judge David O. Carter, long known as brash, verbose and stubbornly hands-on, has been on a mission to force changes in the living conditions for the homeless people of L.A.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MARCH 19: David Barker, 56, is visting with his friend living in a tent on skidrow in Los Angeles, Calif. on Thursday, March 19, 2020. David is not homeless he works in the area. Because of the coronavirus epidemic city and county workers are working to move people living on the street inside. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus brings new levels of misery to impoverished California trailer park
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: Coronavirus brings new levels of misery to impoverished California trailer park
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus brings new levels of misery to impoverished California trailer park

media:content.media:description: THERMAL, CA - APRIL 13: Coachella Valley Unified School District delivers meals in front of Oasis Mobile Home Park in Thermal. According district website students ages 1-18 may pick up their take-out meals each Monday and Wednesday. Two days' worth of meals are given on Mondays and three days' worth of meals are given on Wednesdays. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bats get blamed for the coronavirus. But bats face their own virus risk — from humans
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Evidence suggests the coronavirus originated from bats in Asia. But some researchers say that, here in North America, bats face the opposite risk — of being infected by human carriers.
item.content:encoded: Evidence suggests the coronavirus originated from bats in Asia. But some researchers say that, here in North America, bats face the opposite risk — of being infected by human carriers.

media:content.media:description: At the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area, Corkie Quirk, program coordinator for the Yolo Basin Foundation, holds one of her "ambassador" bats - a Big Brown Bat- injured bats that can't be released back into the wild, and now live within the comfort of her home.

item.title: A nurse watched her father die of coronavirus in her hospital. She couldn't help him
item.dc:creator: Angel Jennings
item.description: Less than a month after returning from a ski trip to Idaho, Charles "Chuck" Jackson was admitted to his daughter's hospital and died of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Less than a month after returning from a ski trip to Idaho, Charles "Chuck" Jackson was admitted to his daughter's hospital and died of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: Chanell Jackson with her father Charles OChuckO Jackson.

item.title: Bay Area health officers got ahead of the COVID-19 crisis. Here's how they did it

item.description: An early morning text. A lawyer-filled meeting on a Sunday afternoon. Emotional journal entries. And, ultimately, action.
item.content:encoded: An early morning text. A lawyer-filled meeting on a Sunday afternoon. Emotional journal entries. And, ultimately, action.

media:content.media:description: SAN JOSE, CA - MARCH 16: Tomas Aragon, health officer for the city and county of San Francisco, speaks during a press conference headed by public health directors spanning six Bay Area counties on March 16, 2020, in San Jose. (Dai Sugano/Bay Area News Group)

item.title: Chaos and competition for vital coronavirus test could slow reopening of the economy
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Emily Baumgaertner, Melanie Mason

item.content:encoded: As with finding ventilators and protective equipment, states are in competition for serology testing in the race to safely reopen the economy, with little federal assistance.

media:content.media:description: Serological tests for the COVID-19 are performed in the Poliambulanza hospital analysis laboratory during the Coronavirus emergency, Brescia, Italy on April 20, 2020. The tests measure the extent that people are carrying anitbodies to the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, having previously been infected but without showing serious symptoms.

(Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Riverside County reports 209 new coronavirus cases and 10 deaths

item.description: Riverside County reports 209 new COVID-19 cases and 10 deaths over the weekend, bringing the county's total to 2,847 cases and 85 fatalities.
item.content:encoded: Riverside County reports 209 new COVID-19 cases and 10 deaths over the weekend, bringing the county's total to 2,847 cases and 85 fatalities.

item.title: Golf courses allowed to reopen in Riverside County. But cover your face. And no caddies
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Coronavirus: Golf courses allowed to reopen in Riverside County. But cover your face. And no caddies
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: Golf courses allowed to reopen in Riverside County. But cover your face. And no caddies

media:content.media:description: PALM SPRINGS, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 3, 2020: A Palm Springs resident finds the serenity of a closed golf course the perfect place for afternoon reading during the coronavirus pandemic at Tahquitz Creek Golf Resort on April 3, 2020 in Palm Springs. All the golf courses are closed in the desert communities. Declining to give his name, he said he's reading a novel by German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. Which seems very relevant during these times. Some of Nietzsche's famous quotes are, "To live is to suffer, to survive is to find meaning in the suffering," and "That which does not kill us makes us stronger." Also, "Without music, life would be a mistake."
media:content.media:credit: Gina Ferazzi/Gina Ferazzi/Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times

item.title: In San Francisco, Latinos account for 25% of coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Latinos in San Francisco account for 25% of positive coronavirus cases, but make up only 15% of the San Francisco population, Mayor London Breed said.
item.content:encoded: Latinos in San Francisco account for 25% of positive coronavirus cases, but make up only 15% of the San Francisco population, Mayor London Breed said.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 20: Pedestrians walk by graffiti encouraging the wearing of masks on April 20, 2020 in San Francisco, California. Counties in the San Francisco Bay Area have announced that people must wear masks when in public or at the workplace in an effort to slow the spread of coronavirus COVID-19. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: California's unemployment call center is still struggling to process claims
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California Labor Secretary Julie Su acknowledged Monday afternoon that jobless Californians were still having a difficult time reaching live representatives for help with their unemployment claims and said her office is still working to resolve the issue.
item.content:encoded: California Labor Secretary Julie Su acknowledged Monday afternoon that jobless Californians were still having a difficult time reaching live representatives for help with their unemployment claims and said her office is still working to resolve the issue.

media:content.media:description: Joe Marquez, a former sheet metal worker from La Habra, looks for jobs at the One-Stop center in East Los Angeles. The Legislature-approved money will be an immediate lifeline for 76,000 people whose benefits were set to run out April 11.

The southland is entering the second month of "safer at home" orders in an effort to fight the coronavirs and COVID-19 pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: More protest California's stay-at-home rules

item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: More protests over California stay-at-home rules in Sacramento, Newport Beach

media:content.media:description: A woman wearing a Trump flag shouts while walking through gridlocked traffic as hundreds of people gather to protest the lockdown in spite of shelter-in-place rules still being in effect at California's state capitol building in Sacramento, California on April 20, 2020. - Some people intentionally jammed roads while honking and holding out signs while others disrespected social distancing rules by gathering in close proximity, blaring Americana music and shouting to end the lockdown. (Photo by Josh Edelson / AFP) (Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Newsom resists pressure to ease California's coronavirus stay-at-home order
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Newsom said that while areas across the state have been affected differently by the pandemic, the "virus knows no jurisdiction, knows no boundaries" and could easily spread into neighboring counties if they ease restrictions prematurely.
item.content:encoded: Newsom said that while areas across the state have been affected differently by the pandemic, the "virus knows no jurisdiction, knows no boundaries" and could easily spread into neighboring counties if they ease restrictions prematurely.

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken Thursday, April 9, 2020, Gov. Gavin Newsom gives his coronavirus update at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. California public health officials said Friday, April 10, that the spread of the coronavirus in the state might not be as high as expected. Newsom said he was already making detailed plans on how to re-open the state while still stressing the need for people to say at home and stay away from others. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: One in 5 California students lack computers and Wi-Fi. Can the digital divide be closed?
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom on Monday announced donations and other efforts to provide computers and broadband to students during the coronavirus pandemic, while saying "we continue to need to do much, much more."
item.content:encoded: California Gov. Gavin Newsom on Monday announced donations and other efforts to provide computers and broadband to students during the coronavirus pandemic, while saying "we continue to need to do much, much more."

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 01, 2020 8-year-old 2nd grade student Paulina De Loza holds her computer issued by teacher Edith Gastelum, left, at the Ellen Ochoa Learning Center in Cudahy with her Mother Yadire De Loza as some students in LAUSD are issued computers Wednesday morning April 1, 2020. The campuses are closed because of the coronavirus Covid 19, but 63 schools are being used to hand out computers. In addition, students are picking up computers and internet hotspots from schools as well as homework packets. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: O.C. can use Laguna Hills hotel as homeless shelter amid coronavirus outbreak, judge rules
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The Laguna Hills Inn will be used to house at-risk homeless people or those who have tested positive for the coronavirus infection, a judge ruled.
item.content:encoded: The Laguna Hills Inn will be used to house at-risk homeless people or those who have tested positive for the coronavirus infection, a judge ruled.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA HILLS, CA - APRIL 16: Protestor Karen Litfin of Laguna Hills outside of the site of a former Comfort Inn on Thursday, April 16, 2020 in Laguna Hills, CA. The city of Laguna Hills has filed a lawsuit to block the county's plan to use the facility to house homeless people with coronavirus. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

(Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hundreds of thousands in L.A. County may have been infected with coronavirus, study finds

media:content.media:description: WESTMINSTER, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 2020: Healthcare workers tend to a driver in line at a drive-through Coronavirus (COVID-19) testing site at the Westminster Mall in Westminster, CA, Wednesday, April 8, 2020. The site is run by Elevated Health and is doing nasal testing for $125 and antibody testing for $75. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: An L.A. Times survey of Los Angeles art galleries on a slimmed-down post-pandemic future. Some are banding together to weather the storm.

media:content.media:description: An installation view of the group show "All of Them Witches" at Jeffrey Deitch in Hollywood. The exhibition, a group show organized by painter Laurie Simmons and independent curator Dan Nadel, closed prematurely due to the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Newsom's secretive $1-billion mask deal with Chinese automaker sparks bipartisan concerns
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Concerns have emerged that Newsom has committed $990 million — without briefing lawmakers — on masks to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Concerns have emerged that Newsom has committed $990 million — without briefing lawmakers — on masks to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif., Tuesday, April 14, 2020. Newsom said he won't loosen the state's mandatory stay-at-home order until hospitalizations, particularly those in intensive care units, "flatten and start to decline."(AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Column: It's natural to long for an end to the coronavirus quarantine. But we should remember what it has shown us

item.description: Our current crisis is not just a pandemic, but also a human-made disaster of all the things we've grown accustomed to overlooking.
item.content:encoded: Our current crisis is not just a pandemic, but also a human-made disaster of all the things we've grown accustomed to overlooking.

item.title: L.A. school district confronts $200 million in coronavirus costs and a grim budget future
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: The Los Angeles school district racks up $200 million in emergency coronavirus costs, from meal programs to computers, and the budget outlook is uncertain at best.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles school district racks up $200 million in emergency coronavirus costs, from meal programs to computers, and the budget outlook is uncertain at best.

media:content.media:description: SUN VALLEY, CA - APRIL 17: Parents wait in line to get meal packages provided by LAUSD at a grab-and-go food center established on Friday morning at Byrd Middle School. LAUSD is providing meals to students in the wake of school closures as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Sun Valley, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: From quiet acceptance to 'crippling fear,' medical workers confront their own mortality
item.dc:creator: Kiera Feldman, Anita Chabria, Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: With Californians anxious for looser restrictions, medical workers feel caught in a state of perpetual danger, with no end in sight. Some are preparing their wills.

media:content.media:description: THOUSAND OAKS, CA - APRIL 15: Kim Ballon a Ventura County In Home Support Services (IHSS) care provider attends to Marjorie Williams, 84, at her Thousand Oaks home as California does little to track safety of health care workers during the coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic. Ballon is worried about a lack of protective gear though she regularly cares for elderly clients, helping them bathe and multiple tasks. (keep as a silhouette) Thousand Oaks on Wednesday, April 15, 2020 in Thousand Oaks, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite probation approval, L.A. blocks release of at-risk juvenile offenders

media:content.media:description: PACOIMA, CA- APRIL 17, 2020: Dorian Martinez wants her 17 year old son released from a juvenile detention camp early since he suffers from asthma and bronchitis, but so far a judge has denied the request during the coronavirus pandemic on April 17, 2020 in Pacoima, California. He has already served almost 6 months of his 7 month sentence for violating his probation.***Attention Prepress: keep the shadows dark. This is how the photo was originally shot.** (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Newsom is helping immigrants amid coronavirus pandemic. There's nothing Trump can do about it
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Gov. Newsom authorized payments to immigrant workers as reconciliation for their snub by the president and Republican U.S. Senate.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom authorized payments to immigrant workers as reconciliation for their snub by the president and Republican U.S. Senate.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom listens to a reporters question concerning his announcement that California schools will likely remain closed for the rest of the school year, but provide off-site education due to the coronavirus, during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. in Rancho Cordova, Calif., Wednesday, April 1, 2020. The state is not mandating that schools remain closed through the summer break but offering guidance and recommendations on distance learning for schools. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, POOL)

item.title: This Marin County town offering coronavirus testing to every resident
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: The Bay Area town of Bolinas is among the first communities in the world to attempt to test all of its residents for the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: The Bay Area town of Bolinas is among the first communities in the world to attempt to test all of its residents for the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: A kayaker paddles out as a fisherman returns in Bolinas Bay.

item.title: Coronavirus stay-at-home order saves state taxpayers $1 billion after car crashes cut by 60%
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: California's stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus reduced vehicle collisions on roadways by roughly half, saving taxpayers an estimated $1 billion.
item.content:encoded: California's stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus reduced vehicle collisions on roadways by roughly half, saving taxpayers an estimated $1 billion.

media:content.media:description: Police agencies throughout Los Angeles County have been taking part in a nationwide effort to curb driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Above, traffic on the southbound Harbor Freeway in Los Angeles.

item.title: Garcetti: L.A. is 'under attack' and will need to furlough thousands of city workers
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith, Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: In a remarkable State of the City address, Mayor Eric Garcetti said L.A. is "under attack" from the coronavirus, with its daily life "unrecognizable." He said major cuts would be needed.
item.content:encoded: In a remarkable State of the City address, Mayor Eric Garcetti said L.A. is "under attack" from the coronavirus, with its daily life "unrecognizable." He said major cuts would be needed.

item.title: Protests against California stay-at-home order move to San Clemente
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Andrew J. Campa, Teri Figueroa
item.description: The protests calling for the easing of California's stay-at-home orders moved to San Clemente, where a group of demonstrators converged against coronavirus safety rules.
item.content:encoded: The protests calling for the easing of California's stay-at-home orders moved to San Clemente, where a group of demonstrators converged against coronavirus safety rules.

media:content.media:description: Shaun Frederickson and his son Zion, 3 were among the estimated 200 supporters at a rally in downtown San Diego on Saturday. The group was calling on elected leaders to reopen the state.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: L.A. County reports 24 new coronavirus deaths
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County reported 24 deaths related to COVID-19 and 334 cases of the coronavirus Sunday, marking its lowest single-day increase in fatalities in over a week.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 24 deaths related to COVID-19 and 334 cases of the coronavirus Sunday, marking its lowest single-day increase in fatalities in over a week.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - APRIL 18: Coronavirus pandemic has changed shoppers as well as vendors at Santa Monica Farmers Market. Everyone is observing social distancing, wearing masks, gloves and stand in long lines to get get in. Santa Monica, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura County eases parts of its coronavirus stay-at-home order
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Ventura County modified its coronavirus stay-at-home order to permit some businesses to reopen and some gatherings to take place.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County modified its coronavirus stay-at-home order to permit some businesses to reopen and some gatherings to take place.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - APRIL 15: John Dodson, 69, takes his 3 and a half mile walk to the Ventura Pier in the City of Ventura Wednesday morning as the sunshine and warm temperatures brought people to the beach despite warnings about the coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic. Ventura on Wednesday, April 15, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Tourist-dependent Solvang struggles through coronavirus stay-home orders in California
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter, Photography by Genaro Molina
item.description: Solvang, Calif., with its windmills and half-timbered architecture, draws more than 1½ million visitors a year. It's a virtual ghost town now.
item.content:encoded: Solvang, Calif., with its windmills and half-timbered architecture, draws more than 1½ million visitors a year. It's a virtual ghost town now.

media:content.media:description: SOLVANG, CA - APRIL 16, 2020 - - Locals Alicja Clarke, right, and Jusyna Zimkowski, enjoy a conversation while reflected in a nearby storefront window along with the iconic windmill on Alisal Road in Solvang, California on April 16, 2020. Clark has not been working since The Copenhagen House had to close due to the coronavirus pandemic. Solvang is a tiny town of 5,300 people nestled in the Santa Ynez Valley wine country, about a half-hour north of Santa Barbara. Tourists - mainly those who make the short drive from Los Angeles and Orange counties -- are the engine of an economy than generates nearly $200 million in economic activity a year. And without it hundreds in Solvang and the surrounding bedroom communities have lost their jobs while the city is losing $500,000 in tax revenue a month. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protesters fed up with coronavirus stay-home orders rally in downtown San Diego
item.dc:creator: Andrea Lopez-Villafana, Teri Figueroa
item.description: At least 200 protesters in San Diego demanded businesses, parks and schools reopen in rally that ignored social distancing practices.
item.content:encoded: At least 200 protesters in San Diego demanded businesses, parks and schools reopen in rally that ignored social distancing practices.

media:content.media:description: Angela Royal was among the estimated 200 supporters calling to reopen California. The group held their rally on the corner at State Street and Broadway on Saturday.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: California will 'do the right thing' when lifting stay-at-home orders, Newsom says

item.description: Coronavirus cases in California topped 30,000, with nearly 1,150 deaths, as officials said science would determine when they lifted restrictions.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus cases in California topped 30,000, with nearly 1,150 deaths, as officials said science would determine when they lifted restrictions.

item.title: Earthquake: 3.3 quake near Carpinteria
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude-3.3 earthquake was reported at 1:34 a.m. Sunday six miles from Carpinteria, Calif.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude-3.3 earthquake was reported at 1:34 a.m. Sunday six miles from Carpinteria, Calif.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude-3.3 earthquake was reported at 1:34 a.m. 4/19/2020 six miles from Carpinteria, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: California lessons from the 1918 pandemic: San Francisco dithered; Los Angeles acted and saved lives
item.dc:creator: James Rainey, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: San Francisco went mask crazy. Los Angeles shut down early and stayed closed longer, but not long enough. Some lessons from the 1918 Spanish flu.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco went mask crazy. Los Angeles shut down early and stayed closed longer, but not long enough. Some lessons from the 1918 Spanish flu.

media:content.media:description: A handout picture provided by the California State Library shows people waiting in line to get flu masks on Montgomery Street in San Francisco, California, in 1918. Unlike Los Angeles, San Francisco stressed mask wearing, but not social distancing during the Spanish flu pandemic.

item.title: Advocates say hundreds of immigrants detained in California are on hunger strike. ICE says only two
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: Detainees say they are protesting conditions inside facilities that leave them at risk for contracting the novel coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Detainees say they are protesting conditions inside facilities that leave them at risk for contracting the novel coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: Hunger strikers at Mesa Verde ICE Processing Center in Bakersfield captured by drone during a sit-in protest on April 10.
media:content.media:credit: Courtesy of the California Committee for Immigrant Liberation

item.title: This federal judge is risking his life to save homeless people from the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: At 76, Judge David Carter knows he shouldn't be on skid row exposing himself to the coronavirus. But he wants more for L.A.'s homeless people.
item.content:encoded: At 76, Judge David Carter knows he shouldn't be on skid row exposing himself to the coronavirus. But he wants more for L.A.'s homeless people.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 03: U.S. District Court judge David O. Carter asks a skid row resident how long the water dispensers have been out of water while touring the area on Friday, April 3, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. LAPD officer Deon Joseph, who was escorting the judge, said he noticed the water dispenser empty about 1 1/2 weeks ago. Carter is the judge at the center of the Orange County riverbed homeless case. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County reaches 'very sad milestone' as coronavirus deaths rise
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Patrick McGreevy
item.description: In the last week, deaths have roughly doubled and now stand at more than 570, the county's health director says.
item.content:encoded: In the last week, deaths have roughly doubled and now stand at more than 570, the county's health director says.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times
